titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Eastern Parkway Coalition records 2007.016
titlestmt.author: John Zarrillo

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-18 19:25:11 +0000.

physdesc.extent: in nine record cartons, six rolled document cases, one oversize flat box, and one loose rolled item

did.abstract: The collection is composed of the records of the Eastern Parkway Coalition, dating from 1952 to 2007 (bulk dates, 1970-2007). These records are primarily composed of subject files, which document many issues which affected the Crown Heights and Prospect Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn. These issues include community gardens, housing/tenant rights, mass transit, summer youth programs, drug abuse, environmentalism, mental health, public parks, and urban renewal. In addition to subject files, the records include a series of plans and maps for the reconstruction of Eastern Parkway and other streets in the area.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Eastern Parkway Coalition records, 2007.016, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection processed to the file level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection is composed of the records of the Eastern Parkway Coalition, dating from 1952 to 2007 (bulk dates, 1970-2007). These records are primarily composed of subject files, which document many issues which affected the Crown Heights and Prospect Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn. These issues include include community gardens, housing/tenant rights, mass transit, summer youth programs, drug abuse, environmentalism, mental health, public parks, and urban renewal. In addition to subject files, the records include a series of plans and maps for the reconstruction of Eastern Parkway and other streets in the area.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: The collection may only be used in the library and is not available through interlibrary loan. Requests to view the collection must be made at least 48 hours in advance of visit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are organized into two series:

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Eastern Parkway Coalition (EPC) is a community organization based in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn. Established in the 1970s, the organization ran summer youth programs, many of which focused on community improvement and gardening. The group established a community garden atop the Franklin Avenue Shuttle subway station at the Botanic Garden/Eastern Parkway/Union Street. In 1989, New York City Transit Police demolished the community garden with the intention of clearing the land for a parking lot. The garden was later reestablished due to community outrage. As of 2011, the EPC continues to sponsor community gardening programs in the Crown Heights and surrounding neighborhoods of Brooklyn.

physdesc.extent: in ten record cartons and one oversize flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains subject files of the Eastern Parkway Coalition, and includes documents dating from 1952 to 2007.

The files were maintained by Constance Lesold, who was also an active member of other community groups, such as Community Board 8/9, the Brooklyn Tenants Union, and local block associations. Files related to those other organizations appear frequently in the series.

The series documents several issues relating to the Crown Heights and Prospect Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn from the 1970s to the early 2000s. These issues include community gardens, housing/tenant rights, mass transit, summer youth programs, drug abuse, environmentalism, mental health, public parks, the Haitian community, and urban renewal.

Community gardens are especially well represented in the files, especially the Franklin Avenue Shuttle Garden, which was demolished by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) in 1989. Controversy over the Brooklyn Botanic Garden charging entrance fees is also addressed in the series.
Cultural affairs are also featured in the series, especially the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Public Library, and the New Muse.
The files are primarily composed of flyers, publications, correspondence, memoranda, and clippings. A small amount of files include photographs, slides, negatives, and audio cassettes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files in this series were recieved in a disorganized state and are not arranged in any particular order. Unfoldered documents were placed in folders and labeled by the processing archivist. The titles for these folders have been enclosed in brackets.

physdesc.extent: in six rolled document cases, one oversize flat box, and one loose rolled item

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains plans and maps for the reconstruction and redevelopment of Eastern Parkway and other streets in the Prospect Heights and Crown Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn, dating from 1973 to 1988. The series also includes district maps and plans for playground reconstruction. There are eleven sets of plans and maps in total, along with two folders of related documents. The plans and maps were produced by the City of New York.
